author: mightypenguin
content:
Spitballing Engineering question:
Would there be advantages to keeping the 2 post-merge clients (~ETH1 + ETH2) as separate and loosely coupled versus merging them together? If kept loosely coupled it seems like this could allow parallel evolution more quickly...
At this point in time I think we have this nice separation between the two for most/all clients and perhaps there would be advantages to formalizing that going forward?
I guess this would also mean dictating logic flow and separation to clients though...

author: sky.cactus
content: The plan for The Merge is to have them separate.  Some people want them to eventually integrate, others want them to remain separate.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm *weakly* in the "keep them separate" camp, but I can appreciate the arguments made by the opposition.

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect long term we'll see a mix of both.  Nethermind, for example, may end up finishing up Cortex which I believe will be built in to the Nethermind client, while TurboGeth is actively moving toward a service oriented architecture and is very unlikely to integrate the consensus client.
